reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of historical/current “moral catastrophe” examples (esp. §2.1) as intuitive support for eutopian fragility/narrowness. That support is not the whole case (the argument also relies on the multiplicative model, resource-scaling/fat-tail claims, and the bounded/unbounded value-function analysis), so centrality is moderate (~0.3). As a refutation of that particular evidential move, it has moderate strength: it plausibly argues the examples can be read as mere moral disagreement and that treating diverse condemnations as comparable evidence risks question-begging against pluralism/toleration-friendly metaethics; however, the paper’s intent is largely illustrative (“from many perspectives”) rather than claiming equal weight, so the critique doesn’t fully undercut the broader fragility claim. Most statements are fair and non-false (high correctness), and the point is clearly stated with little fluff (low dead weight) and focuses on one main issue (high single-issue). Overall, it modestly weakens one strand of motivation but does not seriously damage the full argument.
title: Moral diversity could support acceptable futures rather than fragility
